In the sense that someone can have something unfortunate happen to them - absolutely. You would be okay to say "I had some bad luck today". Or if you have something fortuitous happen then that's good luck. However in the sense that there is some kind of a connection between any two instances of luck i.e to make the generalisation that you are "an unlucky person" - the answer is no. It implies that there is something regulating people's luck, other than random chance, which isn't the case. It's true that someone can be born into very unfortunate circumstances, in which case the chances of bad things happening to them are increased - you could say they were unlucky for that.  Also the inverse would be true for someone born into nicer circumstances. But this is still all just chance and probability - with a large enough sample of human beings you are bound to get some people who have more instances of good or bad luck than others. Any time you read into random events like this and draw some kind of conclusion, you are committing what is known as the Texas sharpshooter fallacy. The basic idea is that you are cherry picking examples to fit your conclusion, and ignoring examples which don't fit with that. A common example of this might be that you thought about a friend you hadn't seen in a while, then later on you saw them. Spooky eh? What is really happening here though is that you are ignoring all the many, many (many) instances you thought about someone and didn't see them later that day. All of the focus is on the one instance that did happen, which is basically just probability. Sit there thinking about people often enough and you are bound to see one of them at some point! So when you call yourself an 'unlucky person', it's likely that you are counting instances of bad luck while ignoring instances of good. A person's attitude can have a big influence on their luck. Some people are blamers, they will end up feeling that only bad things happen to them and there is nothing they can do about it. When in actual fact it's either that -  They ignore the positive and focus on the negative aspects of their life, when in reality everyone has good and bad things happen to them.They aren't trying very hard to change their life.They are actually the cause of their own suffering i.e they do not nice things to other people and act all surprised when bad things then happen to them in return.Possibly all three. For example you might think that you are someone who "never wins competitions", when actually you don't enter very many - so the chance of you winning is a lot less than someone who tries really hard and enters many different ones. From your perspective you only the see the instance of that person winning, rather than all the times they've tried and failed, and so you might end up thinking "wow some people get all the luck". As the saying goes "you make your own luck".
